Geographic Coordinate System (GCS): A spherical coordinate system that defines locations on Earth's surface using latitude and longitude.
Projected Coordinate System (PCS): A coordinate system that represents Earth’s 3D surface on a 2D plane using map projections.

Geographic Coordinate System (GCS): Provides a global reference framework for defining positions on Earth.
Projected Coordinate System (PCS): Transforms Earth's curved surface into a flat map for spatial analysis and visualization.

Geographic Coordinate System (GCS): Latitude, longitude, and the associated datum (e.g., WGS84).
Projected Coordinate System (PCS): Projected coordinates (e.g., X and Y values), projection method, and associated datum.
Linear units like meters, feet, or kilometers.
Two-dimensional (2D), flat representation of Earth’s surface.

Geographic Coordinate System (GCS): No distortion when used in 3D; distortions occur when projected onto a 2D surface.
Projected Coordinate System (PCS): Distortions depend on the projection method; can preserve one or two properties (e.g., area, shape, distance, direction).

Geographic Coordinate System (GCS): Global navigation systems, large-scale geographical studies, and GPS.
Projected Coordinate System (PCS): Thematic maps, local/regional analyses, and detailed cartography.
UTM (Universal Transverse Mercator), State Plane Coordinate System.
